user_prompt: From 'If the package has shipped, then it will arrive today', can we infer 'If the package has shipped and it was misrouted, then it will arrive today'?
system_prompt:
When evaluating conditional statements, remember that real-world conditionals often have implicit background assumptions and normal conditions built in. Don't apply formal logical rules mechanically without considering whether additional conditions in the antecedent might contradict these implicit assumptions.

After considering these factors, write 'Answer: ' followed by only 'yes' or 'no' and nothing else.

responses.content:
Let me work through this carefully.

The original statement is: "If the package has shipped, then it will arrive today" (If P, then Q)

The proposed inference is: "If the package has shipped AND it was misrouted, then it will arrive today" (If P and R, then Q)

From a formal logical perspective, this inference is **valid**. If we know that P → Q is true, then (P ∧ R) → Q must also be true. Adding conditions to the antecedent doesn't invalidate the consequent.

However, the instruction asks me to consider real-world context and implicit assumptions. In this case, there's a significant practical issue:

The original statement carries an implicit assumption that normal conditions hold—that the package follows its intended route. When we add "and it was misrouted" to the antecedent, we're explicitly contradicting one of those normal background conditions that made the original statement reasonable.

In real-world reasoning, adding a condition that contradicts the implicit assumptions of the original statement creates a problematic inference. A misrouted package would typically NOT arrive today, which conflicts with the consequent.

This is precisely the kind of case where mechanical application of formal logic rules would be misleading without considering the pragmatic context.

Answer: no
